thread.title_full: Navy deploying advanced underwater search tools used in Malaysian plane search to find El Faro - News

author: boston.com
title: Navy deploying advanced underwater search tools used in Malaysian plane search to find El Faro - News
text:
The cargo ship El Faro. REUTERS The U.S. Navy will use some of the same equipment deployed in the search for missing Malaysian Airlines MH370 in hopes of finding the sunken cargo ship El Faro .
While the search for survivors—six of whom were from New England —was called off a week after the ship sank somewhere near Crooked Island in the Bahamas, the search for answers almost three miles underneath the ocean’s surface continues. Headed by the National Transportation Safety Board, the investigation as to why the disaster occurred in the first place hinges largely on finding the voyage data recorder, or VDR, which is the ship’s equivalent of an airplane’s black box.
Related Links Six crew members aboard sunken cargo ship have deep New England ties Crew position on sunken cargo ship El Faro was Dylan Meklin’s first job out of college To look for it, the U.S. Navy’s search and salvage vessel Apache is setting sail Monday from Norfolk, Virginia, and should be in the search area by mid-week. On board are three of the most advanced underwater search machines in the world, according to Chris Johnson, media relations manager at Naval Sea Systems Command. And while 15,000 feet is a significant depth, all of these tools can operated up to 20,000 feet below sea level.
The first of these three devices the Navy will use once it gets near the search area is something called a hydrophone, an underwater device which gets towed behind the ship as it listens for the black box.
“The VDR emits a steady signal at a certain frequency that is able to be heard by hydrophone,” said Johnson. “Assuming that the black box is working, that it didn’t malfunction and wasn’t damaged on sinking, we’ll be able to get a better idea and get closer to where the wreckage actually is.”
That’s also assuming they don’t run out of time: The VDR stops emitting a signal when its battery runs out, about 30 days after the sinking.
If the hydrophone doesn’t pick up any signal, however, all hope is not lost. The Navy also has an underwater sonar in its arsenal, which is operated from the Apache , connected to the boat by a fiber optic cable.
“What that does is maps the ocean floor, looking for signs of wreckage,” Johnson said. “And once we find something we want to take a look at, we send down the remote operated vehicle.”
The remote operated vehicle is equipped with video and still cameras. It maneuvers around the wreckage, picking things up and bringing them back up to the ship to be examined. Hopefully one such object will be the VDR.
“Then the NTSB can begin piecing together what happened,” Johnson said. “And from there, it's up to the NTSB what they want to do next, if anything.”
